block.p: The United States Attorney's office will not pursue felony criminal drug charges against Yankee relief pitcher STEVE HOWE, assistant United States Attorney KRIS McLEAN said in an interview published yesterday in the Independent Record of Helena, Mont.

"After consulting with the appropriate investigative agencies and reviewing the evidence," there is not enough evidence to indict Howe on federal felony drug charges, McLean was quoted as saying. "It doesn't mean the misdemeanor case is weaker. It just means we didn't have the evidence to charge a felony."

The United States Attorney's office will not pursue felony criminal drug charges against Yankee relief pitcher STEVE HOWE, assistant United States Attorney KRIS McLEAN said in an interview published yesterday in the Independent Record of Helena, Mont.

"After consulting with the appropriate investigative agencies and reviewing the evidence," there is not enough evidence to indict Howe on federal felony drug charges, McLean was quoted as saying. "It doesn't mean the misdemeanor case is weaker. It just means we didn't have the evidence to charge a felony."

Howe faces trial Jan. 30 in Missoula, Mont., on a Federal misdemeanor cocaine possession charge. Authorities arrested Howe in Kalispell, Mont., on Dec. 19 after a Drug Enforcement Agency informant charged that Howe bought a gram of cocaine for $100.(AP) SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL
